description: From Late Latin antīquātiō, antīquātiōnem, noun of action from past-participle stem of antīquāre.

entries.meaning: (uncountable) The process of becoming antique or obsolete.
(countable) Something that is antique or obsolete.
examples: What to Planck and to many of his contemporaries seemed perfectly indifferent antiquations, have again come to be regarded as questions of engrossing interest and vital importance […]
